text:
It seems to me that Parquet.jl doesn’t work as documented. It says in the readme that:
```# `tbl` is a Tables.jl compatible table
tbl = read_parquet(path_to_parquet_file)```
However, it doesn’t satisfy the Tables.jl interface:
```using Parquet, DataFrames
df = DataFrame(ints = rand(Int, 100))
write_parquet("tmp.parquet", df)
tbl = read_parquet("tmp.parquet")
Tables.istable(tbl)```
returns `false`.

elements.text: It seems to me that Parquet.jl doesn’t work as documented. It says in the readme that:

# `tbl` is a Tables.jl compatible table
tbl = read_parquet(path_to_parquet_file)
However, it doesn’t satisfy the Tables.jl interface:

using Parquet, DataFrames
df = DataFrame(ints = rand(Int, 100))
write_parquet("tmp.parquet", df)
tbl = read_parquet("tmp.parquet")
Tables.istable(tbl)

text:
I see. I wonder what happened there, perhaps the istable function was not overwritten. When I wrote it it was returning a named tuple perhaps now it was returning a custom type.

The lack of formal interfaces in Julia makes this type of checks harder
